ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Individual and group meetings every week with my project advisor and lab group.
Independent project with weekly updates to professors and zoom meetings when necessary.
I met with my advisor virtually for a weekly meeting.
Independent work with meetings with advisor
Senior Project for CS. Weekly meetings with advisor to check-in.
weekly virtual meetings with advisor
Virtual 1:1 meetings
It was great to work with Prof. Brown because he let me pursue my interests while guiding me when I got stuck!
One on one weekly zoom discussion.
Independent project with advisor
We had meetings by appointment whenever I found it was necessary to discuss progress or future steps with my mentor. The meetings were roughly bi-weekly and a 30-minute meeting over Zoom.
Senior project - met weekly with advisor
Zoom meetings
Since this was an independent senior project, I met with my advisor one-on-one over Zoom.
Personal exploration, online videos and tutorials
I met weekly, one-on-one over Zoom, with my advisor.  In each meeting, we discussed my progress and possible directions of future work, which I would implement throughout the week.
self-directed work, supplemented by weekly meetings with advisor

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Manifold alignment, data cleaning/processing, GAN training, biomedical data
I learned a lot about the specific area I did my senior research in, which was digital contact tracing. I also learned a lot about how to manage large research projects and format a research paper.
I learned more about my specific research project, which happened to be in the field of applied machine learning.
I learned about Data and Information Visualization and the Digital Divide for my senior project.
I learned a lot about how to build a mobile app from scratch and maintain it.

I worked with Prof. Dorsey in designing and executing my Senior Project. I learned how to write a project proposal, speak with faculty and professionals about machine learning, computer vision, and more, and front end web coding.
I learned React Native and Firebase
I learned about auction theory and was able to gain a deep enough background where I started to develop some intuition of my own.
I learned how to work independently on a project developed over the course of the semester.
Research skills
I learned a lot about current political and economic issues connected to technology, particularly focusing on online privacy concerns that have emerged during the pandemic.
data analysis, report writing

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is different for everyone. I liked that it was independent and I could guide my own learning. However, it was hard to stay motivated at some points because it was so self-directed.

A strength is that you have the power to choose the sub-field and even project that you work on during the semester.  A weakness is that the course is relatively non-structured which forces you and your advisor to make your own deadlines.
My professor was very helpful ini checking in with me weekly and giving me advice about how to improve my project.
Strengths are the flexibility you have to do whatever project or research you are interested in

Very open ended, so it's cool to do whatever you want. Also a downside, as it's up to you to do the work on time. Working 1:1 with a faculty member is also a cool experience, and I felt like I got enough time with Prof. Dorsey and got valuable advice.
I could have had more tutorials/guidance prepared.

Strengths: Weekly one on one discussion with my advisor was very helpful because it allowed me to ask questions and ensured that I made progress each week. Doing the senior project in the fall semester is nice because advisors have more availability.

Weaknesses: None
I enjoyed how open-ended the project is, and only wished that there were clearer criteria for a successful project.
Open-ended, but sometimes you have to push hard to move your own project forward

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was great to have weekly check-ins about the project over Zoom so I could stay on track for my senior project.
Meeting on Zoom worked fine, being able to share my screen and present things was a good format.
It was perfectly geared towards online learning
Zoom office hours are effective.
Nothing in particular to this project.
We had a end-of-semester presentation in the research group, which was great for virtual engagement because we learnt about others' work
This class was easy to move onto Zoom, since it is an independent study anyway.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes; it's a good way to dabble in a research area of interest. Plus, it's a requirement for the major :)
It's mandatory for cs majors, so yes.
I would recommend it to be exposed to CS research and see if it's something you are interested in doing in the future.

The amount of work for the senior project is up to each individual to decide, which is nice. You have freedom in what you want to explore, and compared to other classes the amount of stress is more manageable.
Yes, it is a fun way to apply your knowledge in CS to a final project.
It's required!
For sure!
Yes, there is no need to fear the Senior Project. Just pick something that you are interested in and that is doable within a semester.
Absolutely. It is required for CS and joint majors, although it is a great opportunity for anybody with an interesting idea to pursue.
It's a required class, if you're a CS major :)
Yes, it's required for the CS major
It's required for all majors, but it's certainly a good way to explore a new field of computer science or deepen your understanding of something particular.
It is a wonderful experience to have time clearly dedicated to independent work.  You should definitely consider taking this course for more than the minimum 1 semester requirement!
